subject: Fixes a race during v2 concurrent image update

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Think that this is a good place to start improving on our race conditions.

Although, this fix does not apply to all the cases like someone doing large number of concurrent updates at the same time where many queries would result into same updated_at value at the return of _image_get and at query.update(..) to run into this race condition.

However, from a general use perspective and for most of the calls, this MP lgtm.

Would like another opinion for +2/+A.

Thanks for taking care of this!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

It will not work for several reasons.
First, updated_at is not added to values in _format_image_to_db() in db/__init__.py. So previous_timestamp is always None in db/sqlalchemy/api.py. For that reason 
query = query.filter_by(updated_at=previous_timestamp)
does not make sense.
Second, even if we can get _format_image_to_db() to pass updated_at value, it would be truncated to seconds (but we expect millis), due to the way of storage in the database. It means that even after our filter by timestamp another process can easily update values.
Uploaded patch set 2.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3:

Mike, thanks, really nice catch about the updated_at not being serialized. Fixed that.

Speaking about milliseconds precision - this may be try for some database, and that's why the current solution is not ideal. However it will solve at least part of the problem, while the better solution may be to have a dedicated millisecond-precision column for timestamp and/or keep track of the changed properties instead of updating all of them

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

I still have doubts about timestamp precision, but it's a very rare situation when you've got multiple updates in one second. So I think code is fine.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Okay starting off with this approach. We can fine tune it in subsequent patches.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

Thanks for addressing my comments, Alex!

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

While I think the code looks good, this seems to be re-inventing a feature that's built in to Sqlalchemy. Did you look into the 'version_id_col' feature when working on this? Admittedly it doesn't seem to be very well documented, but it provides optimistic locking in a similar way. On the code side, I believe it just requires a mapping added to the db model of the object you want locking for. On the downside we would need to add a uuid column to the db and populate it for the version_id, so a migration would be required.

Patch Set 8:

Eddie, that's right: when I was considering different options for fixing this issue (see [1]) one of the options was to introduce a dedicated version column, which will not have precision problems - and reusing the existing functionality is definitely one of the options.
However, this patch was initially supposed to be a quick fix introduced at the end of iteration, so I wanted to minimise the need of migrations and model changes before the release.

The change didn't land in Juno unfortunately,  but the bug is still tagged as "juno-backport-potential", so we will probably want to backport it to stable/juno at some point. So I would prefer not to introduce changes which may require migrations


[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-September/047158.html
